sn24.3:4.2: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does the view arise:
sn24.3:4.3: ‘The self and the cosmos are one and the same. After death I will be permanent, everlasting, eternal, and imperishable’?”
sn24.3:4.4: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”
sn24.3:5.1: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form, the view arises:
sn24.3:5.2: ‘The self and the cosmos are one and the same. After death I will be permanent, everlasting, eternal, and imperishable.’
sn24.3:5.6: consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness, the view arises:
sn24.3:5.7: ‘The self and the cosmos are one and the same. After death I will be permanent, everlasting, eternal, and imperishable.’
sn24.3:6.1: What do you think, mendicants? Is form permanent or impermanent?”
sn24.3:6.16: “That which is seen, heard, thought, cognized, searched, and explored by the mind: is that permanent or impermanent?”
sn24.3:7.1: “When a noble disciple has given up doubt in these six cases, and has given up doubt in suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation,
sn24.3:7.3: they’re called a noble disciple who is a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, bound for awakening.”
